November 4

New official map: "The Revenge of Darkness"

Hi everyone,

A new map (level 18-20) created by Marfolog has been included in the collection of official maps in Unepic.
He pushes darkness to the maximum, at leas in the first rooms.
Hope you enjoy it!

fran

September 17

Patch 1.50.06

Hello everyone.

In the last months we've been working in portings of Unepic for XBOX, PS4 and VITA.
As we are using the same source code than PC, I could not upload anything until all portings were made.
But now that they're finished I have uploaded a new patch with two new maps taken from Workshop: "Was is coming" and "The Wizard's Basement". They include new unique weapons and equipment chosen by their architects... may they be overpowered?

Due to changes in the source code for portings, glitches could appear. But I'll fix as soon as I find it out. In fact I already fixed a couple of them. :-/ Thanks for understanding.

Oh, one last thing. Another reason for not uploading own content is that I'm working in a new videogame that is keeping me very busy. A sci-fi one... I'm doing my best.

19 comments Read more

Reviews

"...the developer pulled inspiration from multiple games and genres, including The Maze of Galious, Castlevania and World of Warcraft. While each of these titles influences this title, the story, humor, and levels are uniquely UnEpic."
– Destructoid

Steam Workshop

In Unepic everyone can design their own dungeons and share it in Steam Workshop so other players can download it, enjoy it and even test it and give their oppinions.
The dungeon editor includes tools to create huge maps, write your dialogs, customize your monsters and create your own boss.

How does it work?
If you want to play dungeons created by other players, just access to the "Unepic Workshop Page", click on the dungeon you would like to play and hit "Subscribe". Then launch Unepic, go to Multiplayer, create a session and you will find the map in the "Steam Workshop maps" section.

READ MORE

About This Game

Daniel was just an average guy. He was a great videogame player, a big fan of sci-fi movies, and a novice RPG player. In the midst of an RPG, he was teleported to a castle. At first, Daniel believed that he was having a massive hallucination. Eager to keep playing within the RPG to create his own adventure, he decides to go along for te ride until his delirium comes to an end.
Once inside the castle, Daniel is inhabited by a mysterious shadow. This dark spirit can communicate with Daniel, but not control him. The shadow has a simple goal: to escape from the prison of Daniel's body. There's a catch, though-- the dark spirit can only escape if Daniel perishes.
Struggling against enemies in the castle, with the dark spirit attempting to murder him at every turn. Daniel finally discovers his goal: to kill Harnakon, the master of the castle, and free the Pure-Spirits who are trapped within. While the stage seems set for a typical role-playing adventure, Daniel will soon discover that everything is not what it seems...



  • RPG 2D platform game
  • 200 rooms to explore
  • 7 bosses to kill
  • 70 spells to learn
  • 100 different weapons
  • More than 2000 lines of clever dialogue and pop-culture references
  • Full RPG character sheet, including upgradeable skills
  • Quests
  • Potions, Scrolls, Rings, Magical weapons and artifacts
  • Pets
  • Achievements
  • Statistics, including a worldwide leaderboard
  • Multiple endings and difficulty settings
  • Interactive Castle Map, which can be written on and altered
  • ...and hidden treasures galore!
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows XP
    • Processor: Dual Core
    • Memory: 4 GB GB RAM
    • Graphics: 256mb, Compatible with OpenGL
    • DirectX®: 7.0
    • Hard Drive: 256mb disk space
    • Sound: Direct Sound installed
    NOTE: Some ATI graphics cards require troubleshooting because their drivers are not 100% compatible with OpenGL. If you have concerns, try running the demo first.
    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows XP or later
    • Processor: Quad Core
    • Memory: 8GB
    • Graphics: Nvidia Geforce 512GB or more
    • DirectX®: 7.0 or later
    • Hard Drive: 256mb disk space
    • Sound: Direct Sound installed
    NOTE: Some ATI graphics cards require troubleshooting because their drivers are not 100% compatible with OpenGL. If you have concerns, try running the demo first.

Maximum Player
1,059 products in account
73 reviews
Recommended
8.4 hrs on record
Posted: May 24
UnEpic is Epic, no doubts. It all starts when I was looking for something similar to old Castlevania series... The search came up with this game. At first I was not sure about it, but decided to buy - it was worth it. About the game mechanics, UnEpic is a platform RPG. The in-game map is filled in with monsters as you enter each new room, and some important locations aren’t even labeled. Every room is shrouded in darkness, it is up to you to manually light torches fixed around every room just to see where to go. Enemies are incredibly unbalanced, and it’s much easier to survive using projectile weapons than melee ones. UnEpic gets really hard sometimes, don't underestimate it! But still it's really addictive.

Diskatis Invictus
21 products in account
12 reviews
Recommended
34.1 hrs on record
Posted: June 1
"Wow, that end is really cool!"

UnEpic delivers 100%: combining modern "nerd game" parodies with a metroidvania like gameplay. Here are some keywords if you are considering to buy it:

- Castlevania kinda game
- Lots of gear, spells and weapon upgrades
- Very difficult game, it will challenge you and force you to use the skills in order to complete the game (played on hard+)
- Original and funny, they use alot of parodies from star wars, star craft, world of warcraft and even DBZ.
- Quests are hard but rewarding
- Completing it 100% was fun and not a drag
- 30+ hours to complete single player and there is even a multiplayer with unique maps
- Unique graphics: well polished graphics which fits the theme of the game (the store page pics don't give it credit).

An important point which is important to know if you want to play this game: go a range (frost/fire) kind of build, melee really is ♥♥♥♥ end game and you need range in order to complete the game (it will be hell if you don't since you can only respecc once in the game).

CONCLUSION
I didn't like the looks of the game in the store page pictures... but DAMM I was wrong. I enjoyed the trail and error parts and it forced you to play better and make no mistakes. For an indie game they did one HELL OF A JOB. I would strongly recommend this game for anyone who likes the keywords mentioned earlier.

Lucky Thirteen
242 products in account
24 reviews
Recommended
80.1 hrs on record
Posted: July 14
Contradicting its title, Unepic is an epic 2D side-scrolling RPG with a touch of platforming elements.

You play as Daniel, who gets teleported into a mysterious castle during a pen-and-paper RPG session with his friends. Soon enough, Daniel finds himself possessed by a sinister entity who unvoluntarily becomes his guide throughout the journey.
At first, Daniel believes that this whole mishap is just a hallucination and acts as if he was playing a video game, which leads to genuinely amusing dialogues filled with pop culture refferences (World of Warcraft, Star Trek, Star Wars etc).

But well-written dialogues is just one of Unepic's positives.
The locations are distinguishable enough from each other and, if you like 2D graphic, visually pleasing. Definitelly not what you'd call "monotonous".
Controls feel just right most of the time, with just a few design flaws (for example taking damage cancels your targeting, which can get annoying in some situations).
The game's difficulty is fairly ballanced.
You can play on Easy, Normal, Hard or Hard++ and whichever difficulty you choose, you'll get more or less what you expect.
Easy is super-easy. Normal and Hard are the well ballanced "middle course". Hard++ gets more serious.
Unlike many other games out there, Unepic also managed to find a good compromise with providing information to the player. They do a good job of explaining what's what at the early stage, but you don't get the feeling that they're holding your hand.
Another thing that deserves to be mentioned is the voice acting . All the voice actors did an excellent job.


All in all, Unepic is an incredibly well done indie game, definitelly worth playing :)
Read More

facedancer

Recommended
22.7 hrs on record
Posted: August 3
The absolutely best part of UnEpic is the fact that you get tons of (mostly crude) humour, but surprisingly the game itself is also quite playable and offers a nice variety of spells, weapons and fighting styles.
I wouldn't recommend this one for the ones easily offended and lacking any sense of humour whatsoever. I would — for those who value vulgar nerdy jokes and might gladly trade ~20 hrs of life for a pack of lulz. I did and had fun with it!

and Wow the end is really cool if you know what I mean
